books.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:1
verses.text: On Christian Doctrine, Preface: Showing that to teach rules for the interpretation of Scripture is not a superfluous task.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:2
verses.text: 1  There are certain rules for the interpretation of Scripture which I think might with great advantage be taught to earnest students of the word, that they may profit not only from reading the works of others who have laid open the secrets of the sacred writings, but also from themselves opening such secrets to others.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:3
verses.text: These rules I propose to teach to those who are able and willing to learn, if God our Lord do not withhold from me, while I write, the thoughts He is wont to vouchsafe to me in my meditations on this subject.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:4
verses.text: But before I enter upon this undertaking, I think it well to meet the objections of those who are likely to take exception to the work, or who would do so, did I not conciliate them beforehand.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:5
verses.text: And if, after all, men should still be found to make objections, yet at least they will not prevail with others (over whom they might have influence, did they not find them forearmed against their assaults), to turn them back from a useful study to the dull sloth of ignorance.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:6
verses.text: 2  There are some, then, likely to object to this work of mine, because they have failed to understand the rules here laid down.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:7
verses.text: Others, again, will think that I have spent my labor to no purpose, because, though they understand the rules, yet in their attempts to apply them and to interpret Scripture by them, they have failed to clear up the point they wish cleared up; and these, because they have received no assistance from this work themselves, will give it as their opinion that it can be of no use to anybody.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:8
verses.text: There is a third class of objectors who either really do understand Scripture well, or think they do, and who, because they know (or imagine) that they have attained a certain power of interpreting the sacred books without reading any directions of the kind that I propose to lay down here, will cry out that such rules are not necessary for any one, but that everything rightly done towards clearing up the obscurities of Scripture could be better done by the unassisted grace of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:9
verses.text: 3  To reply briefly to all these.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:10
verses.text: To those who do not understand what is here set down, my answer is, that I am not to be blamed for their want of understanding.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:11
verses.text: It is just as if they were anxious to see the new or the old moon, or some very obscure star, and I should point it out with my finger:  if they had not sight enough to see even my finger, they would surely have no right to fly into a passion with me on that account.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:12
verses.text: As for those who, even though they know and understand my directions, fail to penetrate the meaning of obscure passages in Scripture, they may stand for those who, in the case I have imagined, are just able to see my finger, but cannot see the stars at which it is pointed.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:13
verses.text: And so both these classes had better give up blaming me, and pray instead that God would grant them the sight of their eyes.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:14
verses.text: For though I can move my finger to point out an object, it is out of my power to open men's eyes that they may see either the fact that I am pointing, or the object at which I point.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:15
verses.text: 4  But now as to those who talk vauntingly of Divine Grace, and boast that they understand and can explain Scripture without the aid of such directions as those I now propose to lay down, and who think, therefore, that what I have undertaken to write is entirely superfluous.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:16
verses.text: I would such persons could calm themselves so far as to remember that, however justly they may rejoice in God's great gift, yet it was from human teachers they themselves learnt to read.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:17
verses.text: Now, they would hardly think it right that they should for that reason be held in contempt by the Egyptian monk Antony, a just and holy man, who, not being able to read himself, is said to have committed the Scriptures to memory through hearing them read by others, and by dint of wise meditation to have arrived at a  thorough understanding of them; or by that barbarian slave Christianus, of whom I have lately heard from very respectable and trustworthy witnesses, who, without any teaching from man, attained a full knowledge of the art of reading simply through prayer that it might be revealed to him; after three days' supplication obtaining his request that he might read through a book presented to him on the spot by the astonished bystanders.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:18
verses.text: 5  But if any one thinks that these stories are false, I do not strongly insist on them.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:19
verses.text: For, as I am dealing with Christians who profess to understand the Scriptures without any directions from man (and if the fact be so, they boast of a real advantage, and one of no ordinary kind), they must surely grant that every one of us learnt his own language by hearing it constantly from childhood, and that any other language we have learnt,—Greek, or Hebrew, or any of the rest,—we have learnt either in the same way, by hearing it spoken, or from a human teacher.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:20
verses.text: Now, then, suppose we advise all our brethren not to teach their children any of these things, because on the outpouring of the Holy Spirit the apostles immediately began to speak the language of every race; and warn every one who has not had a like experience that he need not consider himself a Christian, or may at least doubt whether he has yet received the Holy Spirit?  No, no; rather let us put away false pride and learn whatever can be learnt from man; and let him who teaches another communicate what he has himself received without arrogance and without jealousy.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:21
verses.text: And do not let us tempt Him in whom we have believed, lest, being ensnared by such wiles of the enemy and by our own perversity, we may even refuse to go to the churches to hear the gospel itself, or to read a book, or to listen to another reading or preaching, in the hope that we shall be carried up to the third heaven, "whether in the body or out of the body," as the apostle says, and there hear unspeakable words, such as it is not lawful for man to utter, or see the Lord Jesus Christ and hear the gospel from His own lips rather than from those of men.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:22
verses.text: 6  Let us beware of such dangerous temptations of pride, and let us rather consider the fact that the Apostle Paul himself, although stricken down and admonished by the voice of God from heaven, was yet sent to a man to receive the sacraments and be admitted into the Church; and that Cornelius the centurion, although an angel announced to him that his prayers were heard and his alms had in remembrance, was yet handed over to Peter for instruction, and not only received the sacraments from the apostle's hands, but was also instructed by him as to the proper objects of faith, hope, and love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:23
verses.text: And without doubt it was possible to have done everything through the instrumentality of angels, but the condition of our race would have been much more degraded if God had not chosen to make use of men as the ministers of His word to their fellow-men.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:24
verses.text: For how could that be true which is written, "The temple of God is holy, which temple ye are," if God gave forth no oracles from His human temple, but communicated everything that He wished to be taught to men by voices from heaven, or through the ministration of angels?  Moreover, love itself, which binds men together in the bond of unity, would have no means of pouring soul into soul, and, as it were, mingling them one with another, if men never learnt anything from their fellow-men.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:25
verses.text: 7  And we know that the eunuch who was reading Isaiah the prophet, and did not understand what he read, was not sent by the apostle to an angel, nor was it an angel who explained to him what he did not understand, nor was he inwardly illuminated by the grace of God without the interposition of man; on the contrary, at the suggestion of God, Philip, who did understand the prophet, came to him, and sat with him, and in human words, and with a human tongue, opened to him the Scriptures.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:26
verses.text: Did not God talk with Moses, and yet he, with great wisdom and entire absence of jealous pride, accepted the plan of his father-in-law, a man of an alien race, for ruling and administering the affairs of the great nation entrusted to him?  For Moses knew that a wise plan, in whatever mind it might originate, was to be ascribed not to the man who devised it, but to Him who is the Truth, the unchangeable God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:27
verses.text: 8  In the last place, every one who boasts that he, through divine illumination, understands the obscurities of Scripture, though not instructed in any rules of interpretation, at the same time believes, and rightly believes, that this power is not his own, in the sense of originating with himself, but is the gift of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:28
verses.text: For so he seeks God's glory, not his own.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:29
verses.text: But reading and understanding, as he does, without the aid of any human interpreter, why does he himself undertake to interpret for others?  Why does he not rather send them direct to God, that they too may learn by the inward teaching of the Spirit without the help of man?  The truth is, he fears to incur the re  proach:  "Thou wicked and slothful servant, thou oughtest to have put my money to the exchangers".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:30
verses.text: Seeing, then, that these men teach others, either through speech or writing, what they understand, surely they cannot blame me if I likewise teach not only what they understand, but also the rules of interpretation they follow.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:31
verses.text: For no one ought to consider anything as his own, except perhaps what is false.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:32
verses.text: All truth is of Him who says, "I am the truth".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:33
verses.text: For what have we that we did not receive? and if we have received it, why do we glory, as if we had not received it?  9  He who reads to an audience pronounces aloud the words he sees before him:  he who teaches reading, does it that others may be able to read for themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:34
verses.text: Each, however, communicates to others what he has learnt himself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:35
verses.text: Just so, the man who explains to an audience the passages of Scripture he understands is like one who reads aloud the words before him.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:36
verses.text: On the other hand, the man who lays down rules for interpretation is like one who teaches reading, that is, shows others how to read for themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:37
verses.text: So that, just as he who knows how to read is not dependent on some one else, when he finds a book, to tell him what is written in it, so the man who is in possession of the rules which I here attempt to lay down, if he meet with an obscure passage in the books which he reads, will not need an interpreter to lay open the secret to him, but, holding fast by certain rules, and following up certain indications, will arrive at the hidden sense without any error, or at least without falling into any gross absurdity.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 1:38
verses.text: And so although it will sufficiently appear in the course of the work itself that no one can justly object to this undertaking of mine, which has no other object than to be of service, yet as it seemed convenient to reply at the outset to any who might make preliminary objections, such is the start I have thought good to make on the road I am about to traverse in this book.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 1—The Interpretation of Scripture Depends on the Discovery and Enunciation of the Meaning, and is to Be Undertaken in Dependence on God's Aid.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:2
verses.text: 1 There are two things on which all interpretation of Scripture depends: the mode of ascertaining the proper meaning, and the mode of making known the meaning when it is ascertained.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:3
verses.text: We shall treat first of the mode of ascertaining, next of the mode of making known, the meaning;—a great and arduous undertaking, and one that, if difficult to carry out, it is, I fear, presumptuous to enter upon.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:4
verses.text: And presumptuous it would undoubtedly be, if I were counting on my own strength; but since my hope of accomplishing the work rests on Him who has already supplied me with many thoughts on this subject, I do not fear but that He will go on to supply what is yet wanting when once I have begun to use what He has already given.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:5
verses.text: For a possession which is not diminished by being shared with others, if it is possessed and not shared, is not yet possessed as it  ought to be possessed.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:6
verses.text: The Lord saith "Whosoever hath, to him shall be given".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:7
verses.text: He will give, then, to those who have; that is to say, if they use freely and cheerfully what they have received, He will add to and perfect His gifts.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:8
verses.text: The loaves in the miracle were only five and seven in number before the disciples began to divide them among the hungry people.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:9
verses.text: But when once they began to distribute them, though the wants of so many thousands were satisfied, they filled baskets with the fragments that were left.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 2:10
verses.text: Now, just as that bread increased in the very act of breaking it, so those thoughts which the Lord has already vouchsafed to me with a view to undertaking this work will, as soon as I begin to impart them to others, be multiplied by His grace, so that, in this very work of distribution in which I have engaged, so far from incurring loss and poverty, I shall be made to rejoice in a marvellous increase of wealth.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 2—What a Thing Is, and What A Sign.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:2
verses.text: 2 All instruction is either about things or about signs; but things are learnt by means of signs.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:3
verses.text: I now use the word "thing" in a strict sense, to signify that which is never employed as a sign of anything else: for example, wood, stone, cattle, and other things of that kind.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:4
verses.text: Not, however, the wood which we read Moses cast into the bitter waters to make them sweet, nor the stone which Jacob used as a pillow, nor the ram which Abraham offered up instead of his son; for these, though they are things, are also signs of other things.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:5
verses.text: There are signs of another kind, those which are never employed except as signs: for example, words.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:6
verses.text: No one uses words except as signs of something else; and hence may be understood what I call signs: those things, to wit, which are used to indicate something else.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:7
verses.text: Accordingly, every sign is also a thing; for what is not a thing is nothing at all.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:8
verses.text: Every thing, however, is not also a sign.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:9
verses.text: And so, in regard to this distinction between things and signs, I shall, when I speak of things, speak in such a way that even if some of them may be used as signs also, that will not interfere with the division of the subject according to which I am to discuss things first and signs afterwards.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 3:10
verses.text: But we must carefully remember that what we have now to consider about things is what they are in themselves, not what other things they are signs of.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 4

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—Some Things are for Use, Some for Enjoyment.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 4:2
verses.text: 3 There are some things, then, which are to be enjoyed, others which are to be used, others still which enjoy and use.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 4:3
verses.text: Those things which are objects of enjoyment make us happy.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 4:4
verses.text: Those things which are objects of use assist, and (so to speak) support us in our efforts after happiness, so that we can attain the things that make us happy and rest in them.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 4:5
verses.text: We ourselves, again, who enjoy and use these things, being placed among both kinds of objects, if we set ourselves to enjoy those which we ought to use, are hindered in our course, and sometimes even led away from it; so that, getting entangled in the love of lower gratifications, we lag behind in, or even altogether turn back from, the pursuit of the real and proper objects of enjoyment.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 5

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—Difference of Use and Enjoyment.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 5:2
verses.text: 4 For to enjoy a thing is to rest with satisfaction in it for its own sake.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 5:3
verses.text: To use, on the other hand, is to employ whatever means are at one's disposal to obtain what one desires, if it is a proper object of desire; for an unlawful use ought rather to be called an abuse.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 5:4
verses.text: Suppose, then, we were wanderers in a strange country, and could not live happily away from our fatherland, and that we felt wretched in our wandering, and wishing to put an end to our misery, determined to return home.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 5:5
verses.text: We find, however, that we must make use of some mode of conveyance, either by land or water, in order to reach that fatherland where our enjoyment is to commence.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 5:6
verses.text: But the beauty of the country through which we pass, and the very pleasure of the motion, charm our hearts, and turning these things which we ought to use into objects of enjoyment, we become unwilling to hasten the end of our journey; and becoming engrossed in a factitious delight, our thoughts are diverted from that home whose delights would make us truly happy.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 5:7
verses.text: Such is a picture of our condition in this life of mortality.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 5:8
verses.text: We have wandered far from God; and if we wish to return to our Father's home, this world must be used, not enjoyed, that so the invisible things of God may be clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made,—that is, that by means of what is material and temporary we may lay hold upon that which is spiritual and eternal.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 6

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—The Trinity the True Object of Enjoyment.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 6:2
verses.text: 5 The true objects of enjoyment, then, are the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit, who are at the same time the Trinity, one Being, supreme above all, and common to all who enjoy Him, if He is an object, and not rather the cause of all objects, or indeed even if He is the cause of all.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 6:3
verses.text: For it is not easy to find a name that will suitably express so great excellence, unless it is better to speak in this way: The Trinity, one God, of whom are all things, through whom are all things, in whom are all things.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 6:4
verses.text: Thus the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit, and each of these by Himself, is God, and at the same time they are all one God; and each of them by Himself is a complete substance, and yet they are all one substance.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 6:5
verses.text: The Father is not the Son nor the Holy Spirit; the Son is not the Father nor the Holy Spirit; the Holy Spirit is not the Father nor the Son: but the Father is only Father, the Son is only Son, and the Holy Spirit is only Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 6:6
verses.text: To all three belong the same eternity, the same unchangeableness, the same majesty, the same power.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 6:7
verses.text: In the Father is unity, in the Son equality, in the Holy Spirit the harmony of unity and equality; and these three attributes are all one because of the Father, all equal because of the Son, and all harmonious because of the Holy Spirit.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—In What Sense God is Ineffable.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7:2
verses.text: 6 Have I spoken of God, or uttered His praise, in any worthy way? Nay, I feel that I have done nothing more than desire to speak; and if I have said anything, it is not what I desired to say.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7:3
verses.text: How do I know this, except from the fact that God is unspeakable? But what I have said, if it had been unspeakable, could not have been spoken.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7:4
verses.text: And so God is not even to be called "unspeakable," because to say even this is to speak of Him.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7:5
verses.text: Thus there arises a curious contradiction of words, because if the unspeakable is what cannot be spoken of, it is not unspeakable if it can be called unspeakable.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7:6
verses.text: And this opposition of words is rather to be avoided by silence than to be explained away by speech.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7:7
verses.text: And yet God, although nothing worthy of His greatness can be said of Him, has condescended to accept the worship of men's mouths, and has desired us through the medium of our own words to rejoice in His praise.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7:8
verses.text: For on this principle it is that He is called Deus (God).

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 7:9
verses.text: For the sound of those two syllables in itself conveys no true knowledge of His nature; but yet all who know the Latin tongue are led, when that sound reaches their ears, to think of a nature supreme in excellence and eternal in existence.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 8

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—What All Men Understand by the Term God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 8:2
verses.text: 7 For when the one supreme God of gods is thought of, even by those who believe that there are other gods, and who call them by that name, and worship them as gods, their thought takes the form of an endeavor to reach the conception of a nature, than which nothing more excellent or more exalted exists.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 8:3
verses.text: And since men are moved by different kinds of pleasures, partly by those which pertain to the bodily senses, partly by those which pertain to the intellect and soul, those of them who are in bondage to sense think that either the heavens, or what appears to be most brilliant in the heavens, or the universe itself, is God of gods: or if they try to get beyond the universe, they picture to themselves something of dazzling brightness, and think of it vaguely as infinite, or of the most beautiful form conceivable; or they represent it in the form of the human body, if they think that superior to all others.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 8:4
verses.text: Or if they think that there is no one God supreme above the rest, but that there are many or even innumerable gods of equal rank, still these too they conceive as possessed of shape and form, according to what each man thinks the pattern of excellence.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 8:5
verses.text: Those, on the other hand, who endeavor by an effort of the intelligence to reach a conception of God, place Him above all visible and bodily natures, and even above all intelligent and spiritual natures that are subject to change.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 8:6
verses.text: All, however, strive emulously to exalt the excellence of God: nor could any one be found to believe that any being to whom there exists a superior is God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 8:7
verses.text: And so all concur in believing that God is that which excels in dignity all other objects.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 9

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—God to Be Esteemed Above All Else, Because He is Unchangeable Wisdom.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 9:2
verses.text: 8 And since all who think about God think of Him as living, they only can form any conception of Him that is not absurd and unworthy who think of Him as life itself; and, whatever may be the bodily form that has suggested itself to them, recognize that it is by life it lives or does not live, and prefer what is living to what is dead; who understand that the living bodily form itself, however it may outshine all others in splendor, overtop them  in size, and excel them in beauty, is quite a distinct thing from the life by which it is quickened; and who look upon the life as incomparably superior in dignity and worth to the mass which is quickened and animated by it.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 9:3
verses.text: Then, when they go on to look into the nature of the life itself, if they find it mere nutritive life, without sensibility, such as that of plants, they consider it inferior to sentient life, such as that of cattle; and above this, again, they place intelligent life, such as that of men.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 9:4
verses.text: And, perceiving that even this is subject to change, they are compelled to place above it, again, that unchangeable life which is not at one time foolish, at another time wise, but on the contrary is wisdom itself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 9:5
verses.text: For a wise intelligence, that is, one that has attained to wisdom, was, previous to its attaining wisdom, unwise.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 9:6
verses.text: But wisdom itself never was unwise, and never can become so.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 9:7
verses.text: And if men never caught sight of this wisdom, they could never with entire confidence prefer a life which is unchangeably wise to one that is subject to change.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 9:8
verses.text: This will be evident, if we consider that the very rule of truth by which they affirm the unchangeable life to be the more excellent, is itself unchangeable: and they cannot find such a rule, except by going beyond their own nature; for they find nothing in themselves that is not subject to change.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 10

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—All Acknowledge the Superiority of Unchangeable Wisdom to that Which is Variable.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 10:2
verses.text: 9 Now, no one is so egregiously silly as to ask, "How do you know that a life of unchangeable wisdom is preferable to one of change?" For that very truth about which he asks, how I know it? is unchangeably fixed in the minds of all men, and presented to their common contemplation.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 10:3
verses.text: And the man who does not see it is like a blind man in the sun, whom it profits nothing that the splendor of its light, so clear and so near, is poured into his very eye-balls.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 10:4
verses.text: The man, on the other hand, who sees, but shrinks from this truth, is weak in his mental vision from dwelling long among the shadows of the flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 10:5
verses.text: And thus men are driven back from their native land by the contrary blasts of evil habits, and pursue lower and less valuable objects in preference to that which they own to be more excellent and more worthy.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 11

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—To See God, the Soul Must Be Purified.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 11:2
verses.text: 10 Wherefore, since it is our duty fully to enjoy the truth which lives unchangeably, and since the triune God takes counsel in this truth for the things which He has made, the soul must be purified that it may have power to perceive that light, and to rest in it when it is perceived.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 11:3
verses.text: And let us look upon this purification as a kind of journey or voyage to our native land.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 11:4
verses.text: For it is not by change of place that we can come nearer to Him who is in every place, but by the cultivation of pure desires and virtuous habits.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 12

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—Wisdom Becoming Incarnate, a Pattern to Us of Purification.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 12:2
verses.text: 11 But of this we should have been wholly incapable, had not Wisdom condescended to adapt Himself to our weakness, and to show us a pattern of holy life in the form of our own humanity.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 12:3
verses.text: Yet, since we when we come to Him do wisely, He when He came to us was considered by proud men to have done very foolishly.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 12:4
verses.text: And since we when we come to Him become strong, He when He came to us was looked upon as weak.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 12:5
verses.text: But "the foolishness of God is wiser than men; and the weakness of God is stronger than men".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 12:6
verses.text: And thus, though Wisdom was Himself our home, He made Himself also the way by which we should reach our home.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 13

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—In What Sense the Wisdom of God Came to Us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 13:2
verses.text: And though He is everywhere present to the inner eye when it is sound and clear, He condescended to make Himself manifest to the outward eye of those whose inward sight is weak and dim.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 13:3
verses.text: "For after that, in the wisdom of God, the world by wisdom knew not God, it pleased God by the foolishness of preaching to save them that believe".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 13:4
verses.text: 12 Not then in the sense of traversing space, but because He appeared to mortal men in the form of mortal flesh, He is said to have come to us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 13:5
verses.text: For He came to a place where He had always been, seeing that "He was in the world, and the world was made by Him".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 13:6
verses.text: But, because men, who in their eagerness to enjoy the creature instead of the Creator had grown into the likeness of this world, and are therefore most appropriately named "the world," did not recognize Him, therefore the evangelist says, "and the world knew Him not".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 13:7
verses.text: Thus, in the wisdom of God, the world by wisdom knew not God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 13:8
verses.text: Why then did He come, seeing that He was already here, except that it pleased God through the foolishness of preaching to save them that believe?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 14

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—The Word Was Made Flesh.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 14:2
verses.text: In what way did He come but this, "The Word was made flesh, and dwelt among us"? Just as when we speak, in order that what we have in our minds may enter through the ear into the mind of the hearer, the word which we have in our hearts becomes an outward sound and is called speech; and yet our thought does not lose itself in the sound, but remains complete in itself, and takes the form of speech without being modified in its own nature by the change: so the Divine Word, though suffering no change of nature, yet became flesh, that He might dwell among us.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 14—How the Wisdom of God Healed Man.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:2
verses.text: 13 Moreover, as the use of remedies is the way to health, so this remedy took up sinners to heal and restore them.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:3
verses.text: And just as surgeons, when they bind up wounds, do it not in a slovenly way, but carefully, that there may be a certain degree of neatness in the binding, in addition to its mere usefulness, so our medicine, Wisdom, was by His assumption of humanity adapted to our wounds, curing some of them by their opposites, some of them by their likes.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:4
verses.text: And just as he who ministers to a bodily hurt in some cases applies contraries, as cold to hot, moist to dry, etc.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:5
verses.text: , and in other cases applies likes, as a round cloth to a round wound, or an oblong cloth to an oblong wound, and does not fit the same bandage to all limbs, but puts like to like; in the same way the Wisdom of God in healing man has applied Himself to his cure, being Himself healer and medicine both in one.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:6
verses.text: Seeing, then, that man fell through pride, He restored him through humility.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:7
verses.text: We were ensnared by the wisdom of the serpent: we are set free by the foolishness of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:8
verses.text: Moreover, just as the former was called wisdom, but was in reality the folly of those who despised God, so the latter is called foolishness, but is true wisdom in those who overcome the devil.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:9
verses.text: We used our immortality so badly as to incur the penalty of death: Christ used His mortality so well as to restore us to life.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:10
verses.text: The disease was brought in through a woman's corrupted soul: the remedy came through a woman's virgin body.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:11
verses.text: To the same class of opposite remedies it belongs, that our vices are cured by the example of His virtues.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:12
verses.text: On the other hand, the following are, as it were, bandages made in the same shape as the limbs and wounds to which they are applied: He was born of a woman to deliver us who fell through a woman: He came as a man to save us who are men, as a mortal to save us who are mortals, by death to save us who were dead.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 15:13
verses.text: And those who can follow out the matter more fully, who are not hurried on by the necessity of carrying out a set undertaking, will find many other points of instruction in considering the remedies, whether opposites or likes, employed in the medicine of Christianity.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 16

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 15—Faith is Buttressed by the Resurrection and Ascension of Christ, and is Stimulated by His Coming to Judgment.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 16:2
verses.text: 14 The belief of the resurrection of our Lord from the dead, and of His ascension into heaven, has strengthened our faith by adding a great buttress of hope.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 16:3
verses.text: For it clearly shows how freely He laid down His life for us when He had it in His power thus to take it up again.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 16:4
verses.text: With what assurance, then, is the hope of believers animated, when they reflect how great He was who suffered so great things for them while they were still in unbelief! And when men look for Him to come from heaven as the judge of quick and dead, it strikes great terror into the careless, so that they betake themselves to diligent preparation, and learn by holy living to long for His approach, instead of quaking at it on account of their evil deeds.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 16:5
verses.text: And what tongue can tell, or what imagination can conceive, the reward He will bestow at the last, when we consider that for our comfort in this earthly journey He has given us so freely of His Spirit, that in the adversities of this life we may retain our confidence in, and love for, Him whom as yet we see not; and that He has also given to each gifts suitable for the building up of His Church, that we may do what He points out as right to be done, not only without a murmur, but even with delight?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 17

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 16—Christ Purges His Church by Medicinal Afflictions.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 17:2
verses.text: 15 For the Church is His body, as the apostle's teaching shows us; and it is even called His spouse.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 17:3
verses.text: His body, then, which has many members, and all performing different functions, He holds together in the bond of unity and love, which is its true health.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 17:4
verses.text: Moreover He exercises it in the present time, and purges it with many wholesome afflictions, that when He has transplanted it from this world to the eternal world, He may take it to Himself as His bride, without spot or wrinkle, or any such thing.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 18

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 17—Christ, by Forgiving Our Sins, Opened the Way to Our Home.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 18:2
verses.text: 16 Further, when we are on the way, and that not a way that lies through space, but through a change of affections, and one which the guilt of our past sins like a hedge of thorns barred against us, what could He, who was willing to lay Himself down as the way by which we should return, do that would be still gracious and more merciful, except to forgive us all our sins, and by being crucified for us to remove the stern decrees that barred the door against our return?.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 19

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 18—The Keys Given to the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 19:2
verses.text: 17 He has given, therefore, the keys to His Church, that whatsoever it should bind on earth might be bound in heaven, and whatsoever it should loose on earth might be loosed in heaven; that is to say, that whosoever in the Church should not believe that his sins are remitted, they should not be remitted to him; but that whosoever should believe and should repent, and turn from his sins, should be saved by the same faith and repentance on the ground of which he is received into the bosom of the Church.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 19:3
verses.text: For he who does not believe that his sins can be pardoned, falls into despair, and becomes worse as if no greater good remained for him than to be evil, when he has ceased to have faith in the results of his own repentance.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 20

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 20:1
verses.text: Chapter 19—Bodily and Spiritual Death and Resurrection.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 20:2
verses.text: 18 Furthermore, as there is a kind of death of the soul, which consists in the putting away of former habits and former ways of life, and which comes through repentance, so also the death of the body consists in the dissolution of the former principle of life.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 20:3
verses.text: And just as the soul, after it has put away and destroyed by repentance its former habits, is created anew after a better pattern, so we must hope and believe that the body, after that death which we all owe as a debt contracted through sin, shall at the resurrection be changed into a better form;—not that flesh and blood shall inherit the kingdom of God (for that is impossible), but that this corruptible shall put on incorruption, and this mortal shall put on immortality.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 20:4
verses.text: And thus the body, being the source of no uneasiness because it can feel no want, shall be animated by a spirit perfectly pure and happy, and shall enjoy unbroken peace.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 21

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 21:1
verses.text: Chapter 20—The Resurrection to Damnation.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 21:2
verses.text: 19 Now he whose soul does not die to this world and begin here to be conformed to the truth, falls when the body dies into a more terrible death, and shall revive, not to change his earthly for a heavenly habitation, but to endure the penalty of his sin.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 22

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 22:1
verses.text: Chapter 21—Neither Body Nor Soul Extinguished at Death.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 22:2
verses.text: And so faith clings to the assurance, and we must believe that it is so in fact, that neither the human soul nor the human body suffers complete extinction, but that the wicked rise again to endure inconceivable punishment, and the good to receive eternal life.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:1
verses.text: Chapter 22—God Alone to Be Enjoyed.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:2
verses.text: 20 Among all these things, then, those only are the true objects of enjoyment which we have spoken of as eternal and unchangeable.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:3
verses.text: The rest are for use, that we may be able to arrive at the full enjoyment of the former.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:4
verses.text: We, however, who enjoy and use other things are things ourselves.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:5
verses.text: For a great thing truly is man, made after the image and similitude of God, not as respects the mortal body in which he is clothed, but as respects the rational soul by which he is exalted in honor above the beasts.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:6
verses.text: And so it becomes an important question, whether men ought to enjoy, or to use, themselves, or to do both.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:7
verses.text: For we are commanded to love one another: but it is a question whether man is to be loved by man for his own sake, or for the sake of something else.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:8
verses.text: If it is for his own sake, we enjoy him; if it is for the sake of something else, we use him.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:9
verses.text: It seems to me, then, that he is to be loved for the sake of something else.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:10
verses.text: For if a thing is to be loved for its own sake, then in the enjoyment of it consists a happy life, the hope of which at least, if not yet the reality, is our comfort in the present time.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:11
verses.text: But a curse is pronounced on him who places his hope in man.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:12
verses.text: 21 Neither ought any one to have joy in himself, if you look at the matter clearly, because no one ought to love even himself for his own sake, but for the sake of Him who is the true object of enjoyment.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:13
verses.text: For a man is never in so good a state as when his whole life is a journey towards the unchangeable life, and his affections are entirely fixed upon that.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:14
verses.text: If, however, he loves himself for his own sake, he does not look at himself in relation to God, but turns his mind in upon him  self, and so is not occupied with anything that is unchangeable.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:15
verses.text: And thus he does not enjoy himself at his best, because he is better when his mind is fully fixed upon, and his affections wrapped up in, the unchangeable good, than when he turns from that to enjoy even himself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:16
verses.text: Wherefore if you ought not to love even yourself for your own sake, but for His in whom your love finds its most worthy object, no other man has a right to be angry if you love him too for God's sake.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:17
verses.text: For this is the law of love that has been laid down by Divine authority: "Thou shall love thy neighbor as thyself;" but, "Thou shall love God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind:" so that you are to concentrate all your thoughts, your whole life and your whole intelligence upon Him from whom you derive all that you bring.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:18
verses.text: For when He says, "With all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind," He means that no part of our life is to be unoccupied, and to afford room, as it were, for the wish to enjoy some other object, but that whatever else may suggest itself to us as an object worthy of love is to be borne into the same channel in which the whole current of our affections flows.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:19
verses.text: Whoever, then, loves his neighbor aright, ought to urge upon him that he too should love God with his whole heart, and soul, and mind.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 23:20
verses.text: For in this way, loving his neighbor as himself, a man turns the whole current of his love both for himself and his neighbor into the channel of the love of God, which suffers no stream to be drawn off from itself by whose diversion its own volume would be diminished.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:1
verses.text: Chapter 23—Man Needs No Injunction to Love Himself and His Own Body.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:2
verses.text: 22 Those things which are objects of use are not all, however, to be loved, but those only which are either united with us in a common relation to God, such as a man or an angel, or are so related to us as to need the goodness of God through our instrumentality, such as the body.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:3
verses.text: For assuredly the martyrs did not love the wickedness of their persecutors, although they used it to attain the favor of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:4
verses.text: As, then, there are four kinds of things that are to be loved,—first, that which is above us; second, ourselves; third, that which is on a level with us; fourth, that which is beneath us,—no precepts need be given about the second and fourth of these.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:5
verses.text: For, however far a man may fall away from the truth, he still continues to love himself, and to love his own body.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:6
verses.text: The soul which flies away from the unchangeable Light, the Ruler of all things, does so that it may rule over itself and over its own body; and so it cannot but love both itself and its own body.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:7
verses.text: 23 Morever, it thinks it has attained something very great if it is able to lord it over its companions, that is, other men.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:8
verses.text: For it is inherent in the sinful soul to desire above all things, and to claim as due to itself, that which is properly due to God only.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:9
verses.text: Now such love of itself is more correctly called hate.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:10
verses.text: For it is not just that it should desire what is beneath it to be obedient to it while itself will not obey its own superior; and most justly has it been said, "He who loveth iniquity hateth his own soul".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:11
verses.text: And accordingly the soul becomes weak, and endures much suffering about the mortal body.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:12
verses.text: For, of course, it must love the body, and be grieved at its corruption; and the immortality and incorruptibility of the body spring out of the health of the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:13
verses.text: Now the health of the soul is to cling steadfastly to the better part, that is, to the unchangeable God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 24:14
verses.text: But when it aspires to lord it even over those who are by nature its equals,—that is, its fellow-men,—this is a reach of arrogance utterly intolerable.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:1
verses.text: Chapter 24—No Man Hates His Own Flesh, Not Even Those Who Abuse It.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:2
verses.text: 24 No man, then, hates himself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:3
verses.text: On this point, indeed, no question was ever raised by any sect.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:4
verses.text: But neither does any man hate his own body.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:5
verses.text: For the apostle says truly, "No man ever yet hated his own flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:6
verses.text: And when some people say that they would rather be without a body altogether, they entirely deceive themselves.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:7
verses.text: For it is not their body, but its corruptions and its heaviness, that they hate.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:8
verses.text: And so it is not no body, but an uncorrupted and very light body, that they want.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:9
verses.text: But they think a body of that kind would be no body at all, because they think such a thing as that must be a spirit.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:10
verses.text: And as to the fact that they seem in some sort to scourge their bodies by abstinence and toil, those who do this in the right spirit do it not that they may get rid of their body, but that they may have it in subjection and ready for every needful work.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:11
verses.text: For they strive by a kind of toilsome exercise of the body itself to root out those lusts that are hurtful to the body, that is, those habits and affections of the soul that lead to the enjoyment of unworthy objects.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:12
verses.text: They are not destroying themselves; they are taking care of their health.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:13
verses.text: 25 Those, on the other hand, who do this in a perverse spirit, make war upon their own  body as if it were a natural enemy.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:14
verses.text: And in this matter they are led astray by a mistaken interpretation of what they read: "The flesh lusteth against the spirit, and the spirit against the flesh, and these are contrary the one to the other".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:15
verses.text: For this is said of the carnal habit yet unsubdued, against which the spirit lusteth, not to destroy the body, but to eradicate the lust of the body—i-e:, its evil habit—and thus to make it subject to the spirit, which is what the order of nature demands.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:16
verses.text: For as, after the resurrection, the body, having become wholly subject to the spirit, will live in perfect peace to all eternity; even in this life we must make it an object to have the carnal habit changed for the better, so that its inordinate affections may not war against the soul.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:17
verses.text: And until this shall take place, "the flesh lusteth against the spirit, and the spirit against the flesh;" the spirit struggling, not in hatred, but for the mastery, because it desires that what it loves should be subject to the higher principle; and the flesh struggling, not in hatred, but because of the bondage of habit which it has derived from its parent stock, and which has grown in upon it by a law of nature till it has become inveterate.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:18
verses.text: The spirit, then, in subduing the flesh, is working as it were to destroy the ill-founded peace of an evil habit, and to bring about the real peace which springs out of a good habit.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:19
verses.text: Nevertheless, not even those who, led astray by false notions, hate their bodies would be prepared to sacrifice one eye, even supposing they could do so without suffering any pain, and that they had as much sight left in one as they formerly had in two, unless some object was to be attained which would overbalance the loss.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:20
verses.text: This and other indications of the same kind are sufficient to show those who candidly seek the truth how well-founded is the statement of the apostle when he says, "No man ever yet hated his own flesh".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 25:21
verses.text: He adds too, "but nourisheth and cherisheth it, even as the Lord the Church".

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:1
verses.text: Chapter 25—A Man May Love Something More Than His Body, But Does Not Therefore Hate His Body.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:2
verses.text: 26 Man, therefore, ought to be taught the due measure of loving, that is, in what measure he may love himself so as to be of service to himself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:3
verses.text: For that he does love himself, and does desire to do good to himself, nobody but a fool would doubt.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:4
verses.text: He is to be taught, too, in what measure to love his body, so as to care for it wisely and within due limits.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:5
verses.text: For it is equally manifest that he loves his body also, and desires to keep it safe and sound.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:6
verses.text: And yet a man may have something that he loves better than the safety and soundness of his body.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:7
verses.text: For many have been found voluntarily to suffer both pains and amputations of some of their limbs that they might obtain other objects which they valued more highly.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:8
verses.text: But no one is to be told not to desire the safety and health of his body because there is something he desires more.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:9
verses.text: For the miser, though he loves money, buys bread for himself,—that is, he gives away money that he is very fond of and desires to heap up,—but it is because he values more highly the bodily health which the bread sustains.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 26:10
verses.text: It is superfluous to argue longer on a point so very plain, but this is just what the error of wicked men often compels us to do.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 27

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 27:1
verses.text: Chapter 26—The Command to Love God and Our Neighbor Includes a Command to Love Ourselves.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 27:2
verses.text: 27 Seeing, then, that there is no need of a command that every man should love himself and his own body,—seeing, that is, that we love ourselves, and what is beneath us but connected with us, through a law of nature which has never been violated, and which is common to us with the beasts (for even the beasts love themselves and their own bodies),—it only remained necessary to lay injunctions upon us in regard to God above us, and our neighbor beside us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 27:3
verses.text: "Thou shalt love," He says, "the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind; and thou shalt love thy neighbor as thyself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 27:4
verses.text: On these two commandments hang all the law and the prophets".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 27:5
verses.text: Thus the end of the commandment is love, and that twofold, the love of God and the love of our neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 27:6
verses.text: Now, if you take yourself in your entirety,—that is, soul and body together,—and your neighbor in his entirety, soul and body together (for man is made up of soul and body), you will find that none of the classes of things that are to be loved is overlooked in these two commandments.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 27:7
verses.text: For though, when the love of God comes first, and the measure of our love for Him is prescribed in such terms that it is evident all other things are to find their centre in Him, nothing seems to be said about our love for ourselves; yet when it is said, "Thou shall love thy neighbor as thyself," it at once becomes evident that our love for ourselves has not been overlooked.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 28

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 28:1
verses.text: Chapter 27—The Order of Love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 28:2
verses.text: 28 Now he is a man of just and holy life who forms an unprejudiced estimate of things, and keeps his affections also under strict control, so that he neither loves what he ought not to love, nor fails to love what he ought to love, nor loves that more which ought to be loved less, nor loves that equally which ought to be loved either less or more, nor loves that less or more which ought to be loved equally.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 28:3
verses.text: No sinner is to be loved as a sinner; and every man is to be loved as a man for God's sake; but God is to be loved for His own sake.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 28:4
verses.text: And if God is to be loved more than any man, each man ought to love God more than himself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 28:5
verses.text: Likewise we ought to love another man better than our own body, because all things are to be loved in reference to God, and another man can have fellowship with us in the enjoyment of God, whereas our body cannot; for the body only lives through the soul, and it is by the soul that we enjoy God.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 29

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 29:1
verses.text: Chapter 28—How We are to Decide Whom to Aid.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 29:2
verses.text: 29 Further, all men are to be loved equally.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 29:3
verses.text: But since you cannot do good to all, you are to pay special regard to those who, by the accidents of time, or place, or circumstance, are brought into closer connection with you.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 29:4
verses.text: For, suppose that you had a great deal of some commodity, and felt bound to give it away to somebody who had none, and that it could not be given to more than one person; if two persons presented themselves, neither of whom had either from need or relationship a greater claim upon you than the other, you could do nothing fairer than choose by lot to which you would give what could not be given to both.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 29:5
verses.text: Just so among men: since you cannot consult for the good of them all, you must take the matter as decided for you by a sort of lot, according as each man happens for the time being to be more closely connected with you.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 30

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 30:1
verses.text: Chapter 29—We are to Desire and Endeavor that All Men May Love God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 30:2
verses.text: 30 Now of all who can with us enjoy God, we love partly those to whom we render services, partly those who render services to us, partly those who both help us in our need and in turn are helped by us, partly those upon whom we confer no advantage and from whom we look for none.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 30:3
verses.text: We ought to desire, however, that they should all join with us in loving God, and all the assistance that we either give them or accept from them should tend to that one end.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 30:4
verses.text: For in the theatres, dens of iniquity though they be, if a man is fond of a particular actor, and enjoys his art as a great or even as the very greatest good, he is fond of all who join with him in admiration of his favorite, not for their own sakes, but for the sake of him whom they admire in common; and the more fervent he is in his admiration, the more he works in every way he can to secure new admirers for him, and the more anxious he becomes to show him to others; and if he find any one comparatively indifferent, he does all he can to excite his interest by urging his favorite's merits: if, however, he meet with any one who opposes him, he is exceedingly displeased by such a man's contempt of his favorite, and strives in every way he can to remove it.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 30:5
verses.text: Now, if this be so, what does it become us to do who live in the fellowship of the love of God, the enjoyment of whom is true happiness of life, to whom all who love Him owe both their own existence and the love they bear Him, concerning whom we have no fear that any one who comes to know Him will be disappointed in Him, and who desires our love, not for any gain to Himself, but that those who love Him may obtain an eternal reward, even Himself whom they love? And hence it is that we love even our enemies.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 30:6
verses.text: For we do not fear them, seeing they cannot take away from us what we love; but we pity them rather, because the more they hate us the more are they separated from Him whom we love.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 30:7
verses.text: For if they would turn to Him, they must of necessity love Him as the supreme good, and love us too as partakers with them in so great a blessing.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:1
verses.text: Chapter 30—Whether Angels are to Be Reckoned Our Neighbors.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:2
verses.text: 31 There arises further in this connection a question about angels.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:3
verses.text: For they are happy in the enjoyment of Him whom we long to enjoy; and the more we enjoy Him in this life as through a glass darkly, the more easy do we find it to bear our pilgrimage, and the more eagerly do we long for its termination.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:4
verses.text: But it is not irrational to ask whether in those two commandments is included the love of angels also.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:5
verses.text: For that He who commanded us to love our neighbor made no exception, as far as men are concerned, is shown both by our Lord Himself in the Gospel, and by the Apostle Paul.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:6
verses.text: For when the man to whom our Lord delivered those two commandments, and to whom He said that on these hang all the law and the prophets, asked Him, "And who is my neighbor?" He told him of a certain man who, going down from Jerusalem to Jericho, fell among thieves, and was  severely wounded by them, and left naked and half dead.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:7
verses.text: And He showed him that nobody was neighbor to this man except him who took pity upon him and came forward to relieve and care for him.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:8
verses.text: And the man who had asked the question admitted the truth of this when he was himself interrogated in turn.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:9
verses.text: To whom our Lord says, "Go and do thou likewise;" teaching us that he is our neighbor whom it is our duty to help in his need, or whom it would be our duty to help if he were in need.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:10
verses.text: Whence it follows, that he whose duty it would be in turn to help us is our neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:11
verses.text: For the name "neighbor" is a relative one, and no one can be neighbor except to a neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:12
verses.text: And, again, who does not see that no exception is made of any one as a person to whom the offices of mercy may be denied when our Lord extends the rule even to our enemies? "Love your enemies, do good to them that hate you".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:13
verses.text: 32 And so also the Apostle Paul teaches when he says: "For this, Thou shall not commit adultery, Thou shall not kill, Thou shall not steal, Thou shalt not bear false witness, Thou shall not covet; and if there be any other commandment, it is briefly comprehended in this saying, namely, Thou shall love thy neighbor as thyself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:14
verses.text: Love worketh no ill to his neighbor".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:15
verses.text: Whoever then supposes that the apostle did not embrace every man in this precept, is compelled to admit, what is at once most absurd and most pernicious, that the apostle thought it no sin, if a man were not a Christian or were an enemy, to commit adultery with his wife, or to kill him, or to covet his goods.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:16
verses.text: And as nobody but a fool would say this, it is clear that every man is to be considered our neighbor, because we are to work no ill to any man.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:17
verses.text: 33 But now, if every one to whom we ought to show, or who ought to show to us, the offices of mercy is by right called a neighbor, it is manifest that the command to love our neighbor embraces the holy angels also, seeing that so great offices of mercy have been performed by them on our behalf, as may easily be shown by turning the attention to many passages of Holy Scripture.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:18
verses.text: And on this ground even God Himself, our Lord, desired to be called our neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:19
verses.text: For our Lord Jesus Christ points to Himself under the figure of the man who brought aid to him who was lying half dead on the road, wounded and abandoned by the robbers.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:20
verses.text: And the Psalmist says in his prayer, "I behaved myself as though he had been my friend or brother".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:21
verses.text: But as the Divine nature is of higher excellence than, and far removed above, our nature, the command to love God is distinct from that to love our neighbor.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 31:22
verses.text: For He shows us pity on account of His own goodness, but we show pity to one another on account of His;—that is, He pities us that we may fully enjoy Himself; we pity one another that we may fully enjoy Him.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 32

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 32:1
verses.text: Chapter 31—God Uses Rather Than Enjoys Us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 32:2
verses.text: 34 And on this ground, when we say that we enjoy only that which we love for its own sake, and that nothing is a true object of enjoyment except that which makes us happy, and that all other things are for use, there seems still to be something that requires explanation.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 32:3
verses.text: For God loves us, and Holy Scripture frequently sets before us the love He has towards us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 32:4
verses.text: In what way then does He love us? As objects of use or as objects of enjoyment? If He enjoys us, He must be in need of good from us, and no sane man will say that; for all the good we enjoy is either Himself, or what comes from Himself.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 32:5
verses.text: And no one can be ignorant or in doubt as to the fact that the light stands in no need of the glitter of the things it has itself lit up.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 32:6
verses.text: The Psalmist says most plainly, "I said to the Lord, Thou art my God, for Thou needest not my goodness".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 32:7
verses.text: He does not enjoy us then, but makes use of us.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 32:8
verses.text: For if He neither enjoys nor uses us, I am at a loss to discover in what way He can love us.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:1
verses.text: Chapter 32—In What Way God Uses Man.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:2
verses.text: 35 But neither does He use after our fashion of using.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:3
verses.text: For when we use objects, we do so with a view to the full enjoyment of the goodness of God.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:4
verses.text: God, however, in His use of us, has reference to His own goodness.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:5
verses.text: For it is because He is good we exist; and so far as we truly exist we are good.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:6
verses.text: And, further, because He is also just, we cannot with impunity be evil; and so far as we are evil, so far is our existence less complete.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:7
verses.text: Now He is the first and supreme existence, who is altogether unchangeable, and who could say in the fullest sense of the words, "I AM That I AM," and "Thou shalt say to them, I AM hath sent me unto you;" so that all other things that exist, both owe their existence entirely to Him, and are good only so far as He has given it to them to be so.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:8
verses.text: That use, then, which God is said to make of us has no reference to His own advantage, but to ours only; and, so far as He is concerned, has reference only to His goodness.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:9
verses.text: When we take pity upon a man and care for him, it is for his advantage we do so; but somehow or other our own advantage follows by a sort of natural consequence, for God does not leave the mercy we show to him who needs it to go without reward.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 33:10
verses.text: Now this is our highest reward, that we should fully enjoy Him, and that all who enjoy Him should enjoy one another in Him.

chapters.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 34

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 34:1
verses.text: Chapter 33—In What Way Man Should Be Enjoyed.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 34:2
verses.text: 36 For if we find our happiness complete in one another, we stop short upon the road, and place our hope of happiness in man or angel.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 34:3
verses.text: Now the proud man and the proud angel arrogate this to themselves, and are glad to have the hope of others fixed upon them.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 34:4
verses.text: But, on the contrary, the holy man and the holy angel, even when we are weary and anxious to stay with them and rest in them, set themselves to recruit our energies with the provision which they have received of God for us or for themselves; and then urge us thus refreshed to go on our way towards Him, in the enjoyment of whom we find our common happiness.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 34:5
verses.text: For even the apostle exclaims, "Was Paul crucified for you? or were ye baptized in the name of Paul?" and again: "Neither is he that planteth anything, neither he that watereth; but God that giveth the increase".

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 34:6
verses.text: And the angel admonisheth the man who is about to worship him, that he should rather worship Him who is his Master, and under whom he himself is a fellow-servant.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 34:7
verses.text: 37 But when you have joy of a man in God, it is God rather than man that you enjoy.

verses.name: Augustine: On Christian Doctrine Book I 34:8
